specs.title: HTML
description: defines the 5th major revision of the core language of the World Wide Web: the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML)
notes: “HTML 5.1” has been published as an initial working draft; simultaneously, “HTML 5” reached the “candidate recommendation” status - *December 2012*.

The “HTML living standard” maps to the following W3C publications: “HTML 5” ([TR/html51/](#) and [TR/html5/](#)), “HTML Microdata” ([TR/microdata/](#)), “HTML Canvas 2D Context” ([TR/2dcontext2/](#) and [TR/2dcontext/](#)), “Web Workers” ([TR/workers/](#)), “Server-Sent Events” ([TR/eventsource/](#)), “The WebSocket API” ([TR/websockets/](#)), “HTML5 Web Messaging” ([TR/webmessaging/](#)), “Web Storage” ([TR/webstorage/](#)), and “The srcset attribute” (preliminary draft).

specs.title: HTML Language reference
description: describes the HTML markup language and provides details to help producers of HTML content create documents that conform to the language
notes: This is a non-normative reference.

specs.title: HTML Design principles
description: describes the set of guiding principles used by the HTML Working Group for the development of HTML5; the principles offer guidance for the design of HTML in the areas of compatibility, utility and interoperability

specs.title: HTML Microdata
description: defines the HTML microdata mechanism, which  allows machine-readable data to be embedded in HTML documents

e.g. `

My name is Elizabeth.

`

specs.title: Polyglot markup
description: a document that uses polyglot markup is a document that is a stream of bytes that parses into identical document trees (with the exception of the `xmlns` attribute on the root element) when processed as HTML and when processed as XML

specs.title: Providing useful text alternatives
description: contains author conformance requirements for use of the `alt` attribute in HTML5 and best practice guidance for authors of HTML documents on providing text alternatives for images

specs.title: Quirks mode
description: enumerates some of the quirks that currently exist in web browsers

specs.title: The `<main>` element
description: the `<main>` element formalises the common practice of identification of the main content section of a document using the id values such as `'content'` and `'main'`
notes: The contents of this specification have been merged into the “HTML 5.1” standard which now **supersedes** this specification; see <kbd>3</kbd> -- *January 2013*.
According to editor, the majority of developers, and implementers are in favor of this specification; see <kbd>3</kbd> -- *January 2013*.
The `<main>` element has been included into the “HTML Living Standard” -- *January 2013*.
Implemented in **non-stable Firefox** (version 21, *January 2013*), and **WebKit** (changeset 140341, *January 2013*), which is in **non-stable Chrome** (version 26).

text: Robin Berjon: “The `<main>` element has landed in HTML”
Dudley Storey: “HTML 5.1 and the main element”
Ian Devlin: “Further examples on using the main element”

specs.title: The `<picture>` element
description: the `<picture>` element is an image whose source content is determined by one or more CSS media queries

text: “Use Cases and Requirements for Standardizing Responsive Images”

specs.title: The `capture` attribute
description: defines an HTML form extension that facilitates user access to a device's media capture mechanism, such as a camera, or microphone, from within a file upload control
specifies a `capture` Boolean attribute, e.g. `<input type="file" name="image" accept="image/*" capture>`
notes: The actual name of this standard is “HTML Media Capture”.
This standard is a “Last Call” working draft; comments are welcome through 19 April.

specs.title: The `longdesc` attribute
description: defines a `longdesc` attribute to link extended descriptions with images in HTML5-based content
enables web authors to provide longer text descriptions for complex images
notes: This is a FPWD (first public working draft) - *March 2013*.
This official name of this standard is “HTML Image Description Extension”.

specs.title: The `srcset` attribute
description: when authors adapt their sites for high-resolution displays, they often need to be able to use different assets representing the same image; we address this need for adaptive, bitmapped content images by adding a `srcset` attribute to the `` element
notes: This standard is derived from the “HTML Living standard”.

specs.title: The `style` attribute
description: markup languages such as HTML, and SVG provide a `style` attribute on most elements, to hold inline style information that applies to those elements; this standard describes the syntax and interpretation of the CSS fragment that can be used in such `style` attributes

specs.title: Introduction to web components
description: this document is a non-normative reference, which aims to provide an overview of how Web Components work; it summarizes the normative information in the respective specifications in an easy-to-digest prose and illustration
notes: Since January 2012, the “Web Components” team actively posts on Google+ (linked below).

text: Eric Bidelman: “Web Components and future of web development”

specs.title: Web components
description: Web components are a way to include and reuse HTML documents in other HTML documents

specs.title: Shadow DOM
description: describes a method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM subtrees and how these subtrees interact with each other within the DOM
defines the `ShadowRoot` constructor

notes: **WebKit** provides experimental implementation. However, in [changeset 137408](#) (*December 2012*) the `ShadowRoot` global constructor has been removed in favor of the `.webkitCreateShadowRoot()` *Element* method. This implementation is available in **Chrome** (version 25). (Also implemented are the other extensions to the *Element* interface: `.webkitShadowRoot`, and `.webkitPseudo`).

text: Angelina Fabbro: “Writing modular frontend components in 2013”
Eric Bidelman: “Shadow DOM 201 - CSS and Styling”

specs.title: HTML Templates
description: describes a method for declaring inert DOM subtrees in HTML and manipulating them to instantiate document fragments with identical contents
specifies the `<template>` element
notes: This is the first public working draft of this specification -- *February 2013*.
Implemented in **non-stable Chrome** (version 26) -- *February 2013*.

text: Eric Bidelman: “HTML's New Template Tag, standardizing client-side templating”

specs.title: Custom elements
description: describes the method for enabling the author to define and use new types of DOM elements in a document

notes: **Non-stable Chrome** (version 27) implements `document.register()` -- *February 2013*.
**Non-stable Firefox** (version 22) implements `document.register()` experimentally; behind `dom.webcomponents.enabled` -- *March 2013*.

specs.title: SVG
description: SVG is a modularized language for describing two-dimensional vector and mixed vector/raster graphics in XML

text: Johnny Simpson: “What is SVG? [Guide to SVG Part 1]”
Johnny Simpson: “What is SVG? [Guide to SVG Part 2]”
Adam Coulombe: “Interactive Infographic with SVG and CSS Animations”

specs.title: MathML
description: MathML is an XML application for describing mathematical notation and capturing both its structure and content; the goal of MathML is to enable mathematics to be served, received, and processed on the World Wide Web, just as HTML has enabled this functionality for text
notes: For demos, see Mozilla’s “MathML Torture Test” <kbd>5</kbd> (view in Firefox).
Implemented in **Firefox**, and **Opera** (pre-WebKit).
**Chrome** contains an implementation which is currently disabled due to a security issue -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: WebVTT
description: the WebVTT format (Web Video Text Tracks) is a format intended for marking up external text track resources; the main use for WebVTT files is captioning video content

specs.title: TTML
description: specifies the Timed Text Markup Language (TTML) in terms of a vocabulary and semantics thereof
notes: The first edition of this standard has been published as an recommendation in 2010. The second edition has now been published as an initial working draft -- *January 2013*.

text: Simple delivery profile for closed captions

specs.title: RDFa in HTML
description: defines rules and guidelines for adapting the RDFa Core specifications for use in HTML5
e.g. `…`
notes: The Wikipedia article (linked below) provides a good example.
This standard is a “Last Call” working draft; comments are welcome through 28 February -- *February 2013*.

text: Manu Sporny: “Mythical Differences: RDFa Lite vs. Microdata”

specs.title: CSS 2.1
description: consists of all CSS features that are implemented interoperably for HTML and XML at the date of publication of the recommendation

specs.title: Syntax
description: describes, in general terms, the basic structure and syntax of CSS stylesheets
defines, in detail, the syntax and parsing of CSS - how to turn a stream of bytes into a meaningful stylesheet
notes: Simon Sapin has started to work on this module; see <kbd>3</kbd> -- *February 2013*.
via [@0penWeb](#): Tab Atkins has rewritten the algorithm for parsing CSS from a state machine one to a recursive-descent one; see <kbd>4</kbd> -- *February 2013*.

text: Tab Atkins Jr.: “[css3-syntax] Parser rewritten as recursive-descent, review requested”

specs.title: Cascading and inheritance
description: describes how values are assigned to properties through the process of cascading
notes: This document was in hiatus since 2005, but has now been updated with a new working draft. One of the additions is the `all` property, which when set to `default` (e.g. `.widget { all: default }`) blocks all inheritance, and resets all properties  -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Selectors
description: describes the selectors for CSS
e.g. `#foo`, `.bar`, `[name="baz"]`, `:hover`
notes: Not to be confused with the “Selectors API” standard.
Peter-Paul Koch released two compatibility tables (for desktop and mobile browsers); see <kbd>6</kbd>, and <kbd>7</kbd> -- *February 2013*.
Level 4 selectors are not implemented. Almost all level 3 selectors are widely implemented. For detailed information, see PPK’s compatibility tables (linked below).

specs.title: Namespaces
description: defines the syntax for using namespaces in CSS
e.g. `@namespace toto "http://toto.example.org";`

specs.title: Variables
description: defines variables which are a primitive value type that is accepted by all properties
e.g. `var-my-color: #06c;`, and then `background-color: var(my-color);`
notes: For current discussions, see the threads <kbd>4</kbd>, and <kbd>5</kbd> -- *February 2013*.
This draft is about to enter “Last Call” phase; see <kbd>7</kbd>
**WebKit** provides an experimental (prefixed) implementation; available in **Chrome** behind the “Enable experimental WebKit features” flag.

text: Jens O. Meiert: “Re: [css-variables] Different syntax for variable definition and use”
Comment from editor about “Last Call” phase

specs.title: Generated and replaced content
description: describes how to insert and move content around a document, in order to create things like footnotes, and section numbering
e.g. (selectors) `::after`, (properties) `counter-increment`, `content`

specs.title: Hierarchies
description: contains the features of CSS relating to the hierarchical nesting of style rules; the main extension compared to CSS 2.1 is the ability to nest a style rule within another rule, allowing greater modularisation and readibility of CSS documents

specs.title: Pseudo-elements
description: extracts the notion of pseudo-elements from the Selectors 3 specification and proposes to extend it to be able to create and style an arbitrary number of pseudo-elements before, after an element
notes: This preliminary draft has been submitted by Adobe for discussion.
This draft is **not ready** for implementation.

specs.title: Conditional rules
description: contains the features of CSS for conditional processing of parts of style sheets, conditioned on capabilities of the processor or the document the style sheet is being applied to
specifies the `@media`, and `@supports` at-rules, e.g. `@supports ( display: flex ) { … }`
specifies the `CSS.supports()` function and other APIs, e.g. `if (CSS.supports('display', 'flex')) { … }`

text: “Native CSS feature detection via the @supports rule”

notes: **Opera** implements `@supports`, and an older version of the API, specifically the `supportsCSS()` global function which has been replaced by `CSS.supports() in the spec` (article linked below).
**Firefox** implements `@supports` behind `layout.css.supports-rule.enabled` flag. **Non-stable Firefox** (version 20) implements `CSS.supports()` -- *December 2012*.
**WebKit** implements `@supports` in [changeset 131783](#) (*October 2012*), and `CSS.supports()` in [changeset 142739](#) (*February 2013*). Both have yet to appear in **Chrome**.

specs.title: Media queries
description: defines media queries
e.g. `@media (min-width:500px) { … }`
notes: A preliminary “Level 4” draft has been submitted (linked below).

text: Stu Cox: “The Good & Bad of Level 4 Media Queries”

specs.title: The `'reader'` media type
description: defines the `reader` keyword for use in media queries which indicates that that style sheet is designed to be used by a “reader” device (typically a screen reader), that both displays and speaks a document at the same time
e.g. `@media reader and (grid: 0) { … }`

specs.title: The `'view-mode'` media feature
description: defines a media feature to match the different visual presentation modes that can be applied to web applications
e.g. `@media handheld and (view-mode: fullscreen) { … }`

specs.title: Device adaptation
description: provides a way for an author to specify, in CSS, the size, zoom factor, and orientation of the viewport that is used as the base for the initial containing block
specifies the `@viewport` rule, and properties like `min-zoom`, `max-zoom`, and `orientation`

notes: **Opera** adds experimental prefixed implementation, e.g. `@-o-viewport` (article linked below) -- *March 2011*.
**IE10** implements prefixed `@-ms-viewport` (article linked below).

specs.title: Mobile text size adjustment
description: contains features of CSS relating to one possible mechanism for adapting pages designed for desktop computer displays for display on smaller screens such as those of mobile phones
specifies the `text-size-adjust` property

specs.title: Values and units
description: describes the common values and units that CSS properties accept and the syntax used for describing them in CSS property definitions

notes: See PPK’s tables <kbd>6</kbd>, and <kbd>7</kbd>.

specs.title: Color
description: describes color values and properties for foreground color and group opacity
(properties) `color`, `opacity`, (units) `red`, `#F00`, `rgb(255,0,0)`

specs.title: Image values and replaced content
description: defines `<image>` values (including gradients), e.g. `url(image.png)`, `image('sprites.svg#xywh=40,0,20,20')`, and `linear-gradient(white, gray)`

notes: See PPK’s tables <kbd>7</kbd>, and <kbd>8</kbd>.

text: Ana Tudor: “Dig deep into CSS gradients”

specs.title: Basic user interface
description: defines user interface related selectors, properties and values
e.g. (selectors) `:active`, `:default`, `:valid`, (properties) `box-sizing`, `outline`, `resize`

notes: For details, see PPK’s tables <kbd>5</kbd>, and <kbd>6</kbd>.

text: Peter Müller: “CSS3 Lifelike: A Slightly Different Box Model with `{box-sizing:border-box}`”

specs.title: Presentation levels
description: defines presentation levels which are integer values attached to elements in a document; elements that are below, at, or above a certain threshold can be styled differently
specs the `presentation-level` property, and the `:below-level`, `:at-level`, and `:above-level` pseudo-classes

specs.title: Basic box model
description: defines the basic types of boxes: block, list item, inline, etc.; and some of their properties, including margins, padding and width/height
defines a layout called a “flow” in which a series of boxes is laid out one after the other, and it defines “floating” boxes
e.g. (properties) `display`, `float`, `overflow`, `margin`, `padding`, `width`, `min/max-width`
notes: The latest working draft was released in 2007 and is considered outdated. However, the latest editor’s draft (linked below) is quite recent.

specs.title: Box alignment
description: contains the features of CSS relating to the alignment of boxes within their containers in the various CSS box layout models: block layout, table layout, flex layout, and grid layout
specifies six properties: `justify-self`, `align-self`, `justify-content`, `align-content`, `justify-items`, `align-items`
notes: This is a first public draft and is not stable!
This document overlaps with the “Flexible box layout” module, chapter 8: “Alignment” resulting in duplicate definitions.
I haven’t contacted the editor, but from what I can see, this initial draft is ***not ready for implementations*** -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Intrinsic and extrinsic sizing
description: extends the CSS sizing properties with keywords that represent content-based “intrinsic” sizes and context-based “extrinsic” sizes, allowing CSS to more easily describe boxes that fit their content or fit into a particular layout context
specifies new keyword values `fill-available`, `max-content`, `min-content`, `fit-content` for e.g. the `width` property
notes: WebKit provides a non-standard `intrinsic` value (now dubbed “LegacyIntrinsic”) which behaves like `max-content`. This value is available in Chrome, and Safari.

**Firefox**, and **WebKit** ([changeset 120849](#), *June 2012*) provide an experimental (prefixed) implementation (e.g. `-moz-max-content` and `-webkit-max-content` respectively). WebKit’s implementation is available in **Chrome**.

text: Dudley Storey: “Design From the Inside Out With CSS Min-Content”

specs.title: Backgrounds and borders
description: defines features relating to borders and backgrounds; the main extensions compared to CSS 2.1 are borders consisting of images, boxes with multiple backgrounds, boxes with rounded corners and boxes with shadows
specifies (properties) `background`, `border`, and their related properties, `box-shadow`
notes: A preliminary “Level 4” draft has been submitted for discussion (linked below) - *November 2012*.
For details, see PPK’s compatibility tables <kbd>A</kbd>, and <kbd>B</kbd>.

specs.title: Line
description: defines the positioning in the block progression direction both of elements and text within lines and of the lines themselves
defines special features for formatting of first lines and drop caps
specs `line-height`, and other `line-*` properties, `vertical-align`, a bunch of properties that start with `alignment-`, and `drop-initial-`

specs.title: Text
description: defines properties for text manipulation and specifies their processing model; it covers line breaking, justification and alignment, white space handling, and text transformation
e.g. (properties) `text-align`, `line-break`, `letter-spacing`, `white-space`
notes: A preliminary “Level 4” draft has been submitted for discussion (linked below).
For details, see PPK’s compatibility tables <kbd>7</kbd>, and <kbd>8</kbd>.

text: David Storey: “Finer grained control of hyphenation with CSS4 Text”

specs.title: Text decoration
description: contains the features of CSS relating to text decoration, such as underlines, text shadows, and emphasis marks
extends the `text-decoration` property by making it a shorthand for the `text-decoration-line`, `text-decoration-color`, and `text-decoration-style` properties
adds (properties) `text-shadow`, and `text-emphasis`

notes: `text-shadow` is widely implemented; see Can-I-use <kbd>3</kbd>. `text-decoration` is widely implemented, but only for `<text-decoration-line>` values.
In addition to that, **Firefox** provides an experimental prefixed implementation of the `text-decoration-{*}` properties (e.g. `-moz-text-decoration-color: red`); see feature detection <kbd>4</kbd>.
For detailed information, see PPK’s compatibility tables <kbd>5</kbd>, and <kbd>6</kbd>.
This standard was created by extraction from the “Text” CSS module -- *November 2012*.
This standard is a “Last Call” working draft; comments are welcome through 31 January -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Writing modes
description: defines CSS support for various international writing modes, such as left-to-right (e.g. Latin or Indic), right-to-left (e.g. Hebrew or Arabic), bidirectional (e.g. mixed Latin and Arabic) and vertical (e.g. Asian scripts)
e.g. (properties) `direction`, `writing-mode`, `text-orientation`

text: David Storey: “Vertical text with CSS 3 Writing Modes”

specs.title: Fonts
description: defines how font properties are specified and how font resources are loaded dynamically
specifies the `@font-face` rule, and a bunch of properties that start with `font-`, e.g. `font-family`, `font-size`, `font-size-adjust`
notes: For the latest changes (since the Debember 2012 working draft), see <kbd>9</kbd> -- *February 2013*.

text: John Daggett: “[css3-fonts] updated working draft published”

specs.title: Marquee
description: defines the properties to control  the “marquee” effect (overflowing content is animated and moves automatically back and forth)
specifies the `overflow-style`, and a bunch of `marquee-` properties
**implemented experimentally in Chrome (see blog article below)**

specs.title: Ruby
description: proposes a set of CSS properties associated with 'Ruby' elements (short runs of text alongside the base text, typically used in East Asian documents to indicate pronunciation or to provide a short annotation)
specifies Ruby specific `display` values, e.g. `ruby`, and several `ruby-*` properties
**partially implemented in Internet Explorer**

specs.title: Positioned layout
description: defines features relating to positioning and stacking of elements; the main extensions compared to CSS 2.1 are the ability to position elements based on CSS Region boxes, and the ability to specify a different containing blocks for elements
specs the properties `position`, `z-index`, `clip`, `top`, `right`, `bottom`, `left`

specs.title: Flexible box layout
description: defines a CSS box model optimized for user interface design; in the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid out in any direction, and can “flex” their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent; both horizontal and vertical alignment of the children can be easily manipulated
specs the `flex`, and `inline-flex` `display` values, and a bunch of `flex-*`, and `align-*` properties
notes: This document reached “candidate recommendation” stage -- *September 2012*.
**Opera** implements this since version 12.10.
**Firefox** provides experimental implementation (prefixed, and behind `layout.css.flexbox.enabled` flag). The upcoming version 20 will remove both flag, *and* prefixes.
**WebKit**, and **IE10** also provide experimental implementations.

text: Chris Mills: “Flexbox — fast track to layout nirvana?”
Chris Coyier: “Using Flexbox: Mixing Old and New for the Best Browser Support”
Zoe M. Gillenwater: “Flexbox syntax for IE 10”

specs.title: Template layout
description: a layout grid or “template” defines one or more “slots” that an element's content can flow into; this allows elements to have complex shapes and it allows the visual order to be different from the order of the elements in the source document
e.g. `display: "ab";`, and then `position: a;`, and `position: b;` on descendants to make them appear side-by-side

specs.title: Grid layout
description: like tables, the Grid enables an author to align elements into columns and rows, but unlike tables, the Grid doesn't have content structure, and thus enables a wide variety of layouts not possible with tables
specifies a whole bunch of `grid-` properties

specs.title: Multi-column layout
description: using functionality described in the specification, content can be flowed into multiple columns with a gap and a rule between them
specifies a bunch of `column-*` properties

notes: **Opera**, and **IE10** provide implementations.
**Firefox**, and **WebKit** provide partial, prefixed implementations (see PPK’s compatibility table for details; linked below).

specs.title: Regions
description: allows content to flow across multiple areas called regions; the regions are not necessarily contiguous in the document order
e.g. `flow-into: my_flow;` on one element, and `flow-from: my_flow;` on another element
notes: Adobe released a polyfill for this technology; see <kbd>6</kbd> -- *February 2012*.

text: Christian Cantrell: “Magazine-like Layout for the Web with CSS Regions and Exclusions”
Mihai Corlan: “Say hello to CSS Regions Polyfill”
Mihai Corlan: “How to use the CSS Regions Polyfill”
Mihnea Ovidenie: “Magazine-like layouts with CSSRegions” and the WebVisions NewYork show

specs.title: Exclusions and shapes
description: exclusions define arbitrary areas around which inline content can flow
shapes control the geometric shapes used for wrapping inline flow content outside or inside an element
specifies a dozen of `wrap-*`, and `shape-*` properties

notes: **WebKit** experimentally implements `-webkit-shape-inside`, and `-webkit-shape-outside` (and others?). **Chrome** currently provides this implementation behind a flag (“Enable experimental WebKit features”) -- see article <kbd>5</kbd>, and test <kbd>6</kbd>.
**IE10** experimentally implements `-ms-wrap-flow`, `-ms-wrap-margin`, and `-ms-wrap-through` -- see MSDN article <kbd>4</kbd>, and test <kbd>7</kbd>.

text: Hans Muller: “Experimental CSS Exclusions `shape-inside` Feature Debuts”

specs.title: Line grid
description: provides features to align lines and blocks to invisible grids in the document
specifies (properties) `line-grid`, `line-snap`, `line-slack`, and `box-snap`, the `gd` unit, and the `rounddown()`, and `roundup()` values

specs.title: Overflow
description: introduces a mechanism for web pages to specify that an element of a page should handle overflow through pagination rather than through scrolling

allows authors to specify multiple fragments, each with their own dimensions and styles, so that the content of the element can flow from one to the next, using as many as needed to place the content without overflowing
specifies the `max-lines` property, the `::nth-fragment` pseudo-element

specs.title: Transforms
description: allows elements styled with CSS to be transformed in two-dimensional or three-dimensional space
e.g. `transform: scale(2) rotate(45deg);`

text: Mike Sierra: “Manipulating content with CSS3 transforms”

specs.title: Transitions
description: allows property changes in CSS values to occur smoothly over a specified duration
e.g. `transition: background-color linear 1s;`
notes: *“This draft resolves a large number of the outstanding issues in the previous draft of the document. The working group hopes to be able to move this document to last call soon”* (full message linked below) -- David Baron, *February 2013*.
There exists a changelog for this standard; see <kbd>3</kbd>.

text: Alex MacCaw: “All you need to know about CSS Transitions”
David Baron: “[CSSWG][css3-transitions] Updated Working Draft of CSS Transitions”

specs.title: Animations
description: describes a way for authors to animate the values of CSS properties over time, using keyframes; the behavior of these keyframe animations can be controlled by specifying their duration, number of repeats, and repeating behavior
specifies the `@keyframes` rule, and a bunch of `animation-` properties
notes: The main changes between the latest (2/2013) and previous (4/2012) working draft are outlined in Sylvain’s message <kbd>4</kbd>.

text: Sylvain Galineau: “[CSSWG][css3-animations] Updated Working Draft of CSS Animations”

specs.title: Compositing and blending
description: compositing describes how shapes of different elements are combined into a single image

notes: Adobe has implemented blending modes for Canvas 2D Context in **WebKit**, and **Firefox** (e.g. `ctx.globalCompositeOperation = 'multiply';`, see <kbd>4</kbd>). **Non-stable Firefox** (version 20; see <kbd>5</kbd>) provides this implementation.

text: Paul Rouget and Robert Nyman: “Firefox Development Highlights – Per Window Private Browsing & Canvas’ globalCompositeOperation new values”
David Baron: “Why adding compositing and blending to CSS is harder than it looks”

specs.title: Masking
description: provides two means for partially or fully hiding portions of visual elements: masking and clipping

specs.title: Filter effects
description: filter effects are a way of processing an element's rendering before it is displayed in the document
notes: Adobe’s hub (see <kbd>4</kbd>) contains a bunch of impressive demos (you’ll need Chrome with flag set).
**Chrome** provides an experimental implementation (behind “Enable CSS Shaders” flag) -- *January 2013*.

text: Vincent Hardy: “Introducing CSS shaders: Cinematic effects for the web”
Michelangelo De Simone: “A look into Custom Filters reference implementation”

specs.title: Web animations
description: defines a model for supporting animation and synchronization on the Web platform
consists of two largely independent pieces, a timing model and an animation model

text: Jake Archibald: “We’re Gonna Need A Bigger API!”

specs.title: Color correction
description: defines a new CSS property that will help migration towards the correct handling of colors that is already defined by allowing authors to specify a preference for the correct or the traditional (device-dependent) color handling

specs.title: Paged media
description: defines the page model that partitions a flow into pages, by adding functionality for pagination, page margins, page size and orientation, headers and footers, widows and orphans, and image orientation
specifies the `@page` rule, and properties like `size`, `page-break-before`, `orphans`
notes: “This is the first official publication since 2006, and incorporates a ton of edits…”; see <kbd>5</kbd> -- *March 2013*.

text: Dudley Storey: “Tips And Tricks For Print Style Sheets”
“CSS3 Paged Media WD Updated, CSS Print Profile NOTE Published”

specs.title: Fragmentation
description: describes the fragmentation model that partitions a flow into pages; it builds on the “Page” module and adds functionality for pagination, breaking variable fragment size and orientation, widows and orphans
notes: This standard partially supersedes the “Paged media” CSS module (which is in hiatus).

specs.title: Generated content for paged media
description: describes features often used in printed publications; most of the specified functionality involves some sort of generated content where content from the document is adorned, replicated, or moved in the final presentation of the document
e.g. the `::first-page` pseudo-element, properties `string-set`, `float-offset`, and a couple of `bookmark-*` properties

specs.title: Pagination templates
description: describes templates that generate boxes in CSS to display content in a paginated view

notes: This draft is **not ready** for implementation.

specs.title: Lists and counters
description: contains features relating to list styling; the main extensions compared to CSS 2.1 are a pseudo-element representing the list marker, and a method for authors to define their own list-styles
specifies the `list-style-` properties, the `::marker` pseudo element, the `@counter-style` rule, and other features

specs.title: Counter styles
description: introduces the `@counter-style` rule, which allows authors to define their own custom counter styles for use with CSS list-marker and generated-content counters
notes: This specification is about to enter “Last Call” (according to editor).

specs.title: Speech
description: defines aural CSS properties that enable authors to declaratively control the rendering of documents via speech synthesis, and using optional audio cues
specifies a bunch of speech related properties, e.g. `voice-volume`

notes: **Opera** provides experimental implementation.

specs.title: Mobile profile
description: defines in general a subset of CSS 2.1 that is to be considered a baseline for interoperability between implementations of CSS on constrained devices (e.g. mobile phones)

specs.title: Print profile
description: defines a subset of CSS 2.1 and the “Page” module for printing to low-cost devices
notes: The status of this publication has been changed from “Working Draft” to “Group Note”, as it exists mainly for historical and reference purposes; see <kbd>2</kbd> -- *March 2013*.

text: “CSS3 Paged Media WD Updated, CSS Print Profile NOTE Published”

specs.title: MathML profile
description: describes a profile of MathML 3.0 that admits formatting with CSS

specs.title: Behavioral extensions to CSS
description: provides a way to link to binding technologies, such as XBL, from CSS style sheets

specs.title: Hyperlink presentation
description: contains the functionality required to describe the presentation of hyperlink source anchors and the effects of hyperlink activation

specs.title: Grid positioning
description: describes integration of grid-based layout (similar to the grids traditionally used in books and newspapers) with CSS sizing and positioning

specs.title: ECMAScript 5.1
description: standardizes the programming language which is implemented under the names JavaScript, and JScript
defines the standard built-in global objects like `Object`, `Array`, `Date`, `Error`, `JSON`, `Math`, `parseInt`, and others
notes: The next edition of this standard is in development and is expected to be published as a standard at the end of 2013. The latest working draft is linked below. Web-browsers have started to implement some of the new features introduced in that upcoming standard. See Kangax's ES6 table (linked below).
ECMAScript 6 Draft 14 has been released; see <kbd>2</kbd> -- *March 2013*.

specs.title: JavaScript extensions
description: documents the differences between the ECMAScript specification and the compatibility and interoperability requirements for ECMAScript implementations in web browsers, e.g. `Object.prototype.__proto__`

specs.title: DOM
description: defines the event and document model the Web platform uses
allows programs to dynamically access/update the content, and structure of documents
defines core interfaces like *Node*, *Document*, *Element*, *Event*, *EventTarget*, *NodeList*, *Range*, and others

specs.title: DOM Parsing and serialization
description: gives programmatic access to the (web-browser’s) HTML parser
defines `.innerHTML`, `.outerHTML`, `.insertAdjacentHTML()`

specs.title: DOM Events
description: defines an event system which allows registration of event handlers, describes event flow through the DOM, and provides basic contextual information for each event
defines the core event types like `load`, `focus`, `click`, `mousemove`, `keydown`
notes: This standard is partially superseded by the “DOM” standard; specifically, chapters 2, and 3.

specs.title: Selectors API
description: defines APIs for retrieving DOM elements by matching against CSS selectors, e.g. `.querySelector()`
notes: Not to be confused with the “Selectors” CSS module.
Level 1 of this standard (linked below) is now a “W3C Recommendation” -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: CSSOM
description: defines APIs for media queries, selectors, and CSS
specifies the core CSS-related interfaces, e.g. *CSSStyleSheet*, *CSSRule*, *CSSStyleDeclaration*, and the `document.stylesheets` object

specs.title: CSSOM View
description: provides a way to inspect and manipulate the visual view of a document, e.g. `window.innerWidth`, `window.innerHeight`, (DOM elements) `.offsetWidth`, `.offsetHeight`, (mouse events) `.clientX`, `.clientY`

specs.title: HTML Web messaging
description: defines two mechanisms for communicating between browsing contexts in HTML documents: (1) Cross-document messaging, (2) Channel messaging
specifies the `message` event type, and the `window.postMessage()` function
notes: “*`postMessage()`‘s security model is so poorly designed that it’s had academic papers written about how dumb I was, so that’s a pretty big mistake. (It’s possible to use `postMessage()` safely, it’s just that the easiest thing to do is not the safe way, so people get it wrong all the time.)*” -- Ian Hickson for HTML5Doctor -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: HTML Editing APIs
description: defines selections, `execCommand()`, and related functionality

specs.title: UndoManager and DOM Transaction
description: defines the API to manage user agent's undo transaction history (also known as undo stack) and make objects that can be managed by the undo transaction history
provides ways to define undo scopes, add items to user agent's native undo transaction history, and create a sequence of DOM changes that can be automatically undone or redone by user agents
notes: This specification will replace the UndoManager section of the main HTML specification.

specs.title: XMLHttpRequest
description: defines an API that provides scripted client functionality for transferring data between a client and a server
specifies the `XMLHttpRequest`, and `FormData` global constructors

specs.title: WebSocket API
description: defines an API that enables web-pages to user the WebSocket protocol for two-way communication with a remote host
specifies the `WebSocket` global constructor

specs.title: Server-sent events
description: defines an API for opening an HTTP connection for receiving push notifications from a server in the form of DOM events
specifies the `EventSource` global constructor

specs.title: Progress events
description: defines an event interface that can be used for measuring progress, e.g. of an Ajax request
proposes the event types `loadstart`, `progress`, `loadend`, and others

specs.title: Network service discovery
description: defines a mechanism for an HTML document to discover and subsequently communicate with HTTP-based services advertised via common discovery protocols
specifies `navigator.getNetworkServices()`
notes: This draft has been submitted by Opera.
The DEV.OPERA article (linked below) embeds a video in which Daniel Davis from Opera explains how this technology works.

text: “Network Service Discovery API support in Opera”

notes: **Opera** provides an implementation via a custom build; download links are available in the DEV.OPERA article (linked below).

specs.title: Push API
description: defines an API that provides web applications with scripted access to server-sent application data
specifies `navigator.push`

specs.title: Streams API
description: provides an API for representing binary data in web applications as a `Stream` object, as well as programmatically building and reading its contents

this API is designed to be used in conjunction with other APIs and elements on the web platform, notably: File, XMLHttpRequest (e.g. with an overloaded send() method and response object for Stream objects), postMessage, and Web Workers
notes: This is the first public working draft of this specification -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: Web storage
description: defines an API for persistent data storage of key-value pair data in web clients
specifies the `localStorage`, and `sessionStorage` global objects
notes: “*…when I designed the Web Storage API I made a horrible mistake by making the API synchronous and requiring consistency during a script’s execution, which essentially became the one place in the whole Web platform where in theory browsers are required to block cross-process. Since browsers don’t implement that, we instead have an API where there’s no consistency guarantee, which is rather scary.*” -- Ian Hickson for HTML5Doctor -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Indexed database API
description: defines APIs for a database of records holding simple values and hierarchical objects
specifies the `indexedDB` global object

specs.title: File API
description: provides an API for representing file objects in web applications, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data
specifies the interfaces *Blob*, *File*, *FileReader*, *FileList*, and others
notes: This specification may soon become a LCWD (“last call”). Arun: “Review on the File API is encouraged” (full message linked below) -- *February 2013*.

text: Andrew Dodson: “Get Loaded with the File API”

specs.title: File API: Writer
description: defines and API for writing to files from web applications
specifies the interfaces *BlobBuilder*, *FileSaver*, *FileWriter*, and others
notes: Firefox (in version 21; currently non-stable) implements an alternative “FileHandle API”; see <kbd>5</kbd> -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: File API: Directories and system
description: defines an API to navigate file system hierarchies, and defines a means by which a user agent may expose sandboxed sections of a user's local filesystem to web applications
specifies the interfaces *LocalFileSystem*, *DirectoryReader*, *FileEntry*, and others

text: Jonas Sicking: “Why no FileSystem API in Firefox?”

specs.title: Quota management API
description: defines an API to manage usage and availability of local storage resources, and defines a means by which a user agent may grant web applications permission to use more local space, temporarily or persistently, via various different storage APIs
specifies the *StorageQuota* interface

specs.title: JSON Linked data
description: harmonizes the representation of linked data in JSON
jsonld.js provides a JavaScript implementation

specs.title: Web workers
description: defines an API that allows web application authors to spawn background workers running scripts in parallel to their main page; this allows for thread-like operation with message-passing as the coordination mechanism
specifies the `Worker` global constructor

text: Matt West: “Using Web Workers to Speed-Up Your JavaScript Applications”

specs.title: Page visibility
description: defines a means for web developers to programmatically determine the current visibility state of the page in order to develop power and CPU efficient web applicatoins
specifies `document.hidden`, `document.visibilityState`, and the `visibilitychange` event type

specs.title: Navigation timing
description: defines an API for web applications to access timing information related to navigation and elements
the intent is to provide a complete end-to-end latency picture when measuring a Web application
specifies the `performance` global object, including its `performance.timing`, and `performance.navigation` properties
notes: A “Level 2” editor’s draft has been published (linked below); adds support for microsecond time information -- *June 2012*.
The W3C blog article (linked below) provides a very useful diagram.
“Level 2” of this standard has been published as an initial working draft; “Level 1” is now a recommendation (both are available below) -- *January 2013*.
Implemented in **Firefox**, **Chrome**, and **IE** since IE9. (This information applies for “Level 1” of this standard.)

text: W3C Blog article about Navigation timing
HTML5 Rocks: “Measuring Page Load Speed with Navigation Timing”
Adam Prescott: “Detecting redirects with the Navigation Timing API”

specs.title: Resource timing
description: defines an API for web applications to access the complete timing information for resources in a document
Usage: get array or entries via `performance.getEntriesByType('resource')`, then iterate array and inspect properties like `.responseEnd`, and `.startTime` on the entries

notes: Implemented in **IE10**, and **Chrome**.

text: An introduction to the Resource timing API

specs.title: User timing
description: defines an API to help web developers measure the performance of their applications by giving them access to high precision timestamps
speficies the `performance.mark()` function

notes: Implemented in **IE10**.
**Chrome** provides experimental (prefixed) implementation, e.g. `performance.webkitMark()` -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: Performance timeline
description: defines an unified API to store and retrieve performance metric data

specs.title: Timing control for script-based animations
description: defines an API web developers can use to write script-based animations where the user agent is in control of limiting the update rate of the animation
specifies the `requestAnimationFrame()`, and `cancelAnimationFrame()` global functions

specs.title: High resolution time
description: defines an API that provides the current time in sub-millisecond resolution and such that it is not subject to system clock skew or adjustments

specifies `performance.now()`; the returned time value represents a number of milliseconds accurate to a thousandth of a millisecond (at most) and relative to the start of the navigation of the document (example value: `16535890.184645617`)

notes: Implemented in **Firefox**, **Chrome**, and **IE10**.

specs.title: Efficient script yielding
description: defines an API for web applications to flush the browser event queue and receive an immediate callback
specifies the `setImmediate()`, and `clearImmediate()` global functions
**implemented only in IE10; as for now, this draft is not likely to land in Firefox, or WebKit browsers (see articles below)**

specs.title: HTML Canvas 2D Context
description: defines the 2D Context for the HTML `<canvas>` element; the 2D Context provides objects, methods, and properties to draw and manipulate graphics on a canvas drawing surface
notes: A “Level 2” version of this standard has been published as an initial working draft; simultaniously, the original “Level 1” version reached the “candidate recommendation” status -- *December 2012*.

specs.title: WebGL
description: describes an additional rendering context and support objects for the HTML5 `<canvas>` element

text: Florian Boesch: “Why you should use WebGL”
Florian Boesch: “How to write portable WebGL”
Jerome Etienne: “Move a Cube With Your Head or Head-Tracking With WebGL”

specs.title: WebRTC
description: defines APIs to allow media to be sent over the network to another browser or device implementing the appropriate set of real-time protocols, and media to be received from another browser or device
notes: Microsoft does not support WebRTC, but is instead working on its own “CU-RTC-Web” proposal -- see <kbd>6</kbd> -- *January 2013*.
WebRTC `RTCPeerConnection` interoperability has been achieved between Firefox and Chrome; see article <kbd>7</kbd> -- *February 2013*.
For information about the VP8 vs H.264 debate, read the CNET article <kbd>8</kbd> -- *added February 2013*.

**Firefox**, and **Chrome** provide experimental (prefixed) implementations (`mozRTCPeerConnection` and `webkitRTCPeer-`
`Connection` respectively). In Firefox, the implementation is currently behind the `media.peerconnection.enabled` flag. The implementation is enabled by default in **non-stable Firefox** (version 22) -- *updated Februrary 2013*.

text: Sam Dutton: “WebRTC hits Firefox, Android and iOS”
Peter Bright: “Microsoft goes its own way with Web audio/video spec, despite W3C rebuff”
Maire Reavy / Robert Nyman: “Hello Chrome, it’s Firefox calling!”
Stephen Shankland: “Best video tech for Web chat? Showdown set for March”
Frederic Lardinois: “TokBox’s WebRTC-Based Video Chat Platform Now Supports Firefox Nightly And Aurora”
Google I/O 2012 - WebRTC: Real-time Audio/Video and P2P in HTML5
Bistri on WebRTC for Video Chat Services

temp: the project home page provide info about implementation status

Chrome has had WebRTC enabled in its stable release channel since version 20 in June 2012. Firefox has enabled preliminary support in Firefox 18 just this week. Internet Explorer 10 and Safari 6 have no support.

specs.title: Media capture and streams
description: defines  APIs that allow local media, including audio and video, to be requested from a platform
specifies the `navigator.getUserMedia()` function which (on user permission) gives access to the user's web-camera, and microphone streams

text: Robert Nyman / Daniel Davis: “Cross-browser camera capture with getUserMedia/WebRTC”

specs.title: MediaStream recording
description: defines a recording API for use with `MediaStreams` as defined in “Media Capture and Streams”
the contents of the recording will be made available in the platform’s default encoding via the `dataavailable` event
functions are available to query the platform’s available set of encodings, and to select the desired ones if the author wishes
notes: This is the initial working draft -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: Web audio API
description: describes a high-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio in web applications
notes: <kbd>6</kbd> provides info about `howler.js`, an audio library which shims this API (but also provides a fallback to HTML5 `<audio>`).
Kyle’s article <kbd>7</kbd> contains a video tutorial [33min].
**WebKit** provides an experimental (prefixed) implementation (e.g. `webkitAudioContext`) which is available in **Chrome**, and **Safari**.
**Non-stable Firefox** (version 21) implements the `AudioContext` constructor unprefixed, but behind `media.webaudio.enabled` flag. (What else?)

text: James Simpson: “Simplifying audio in the browser”
Kyle Nau: “Web Audio API Quickstart Tutorial”
Chris Wilson: “A Tale of Two Clocks - Scheduling Web Audio with Precision”
Playing a chunked mp3 file, by Thodoris Tsiridis

specs.title: Web MIDI API
description: defines an API supporting the MIDI protocol, enabling web applications to enumerate and select MIDI input and output devices on the client system and send and receive MIDI messages
notes: Implementation in WebKit has been announced -- see <kbd>4</kbd> -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Web speech API
description: defines a JavaScript API to enable web developers to incorporate speech recognition and synthesis into their web pages; It enables developers to use scripting to generate text-to-speech output and to use speech recognition as an input for forms, continuous dictation and control

notes: **Chrome** provides an experimental implementation of speech recognition via the `webkitSpeechRecognition` global constructor; see <kbd>3</kbd> -- *January 2013*.
The `SpeechSynthesis` interface is expected to be implemented by Apple for **WebKit**; see <kbd>2</kbd> -- *January 2013*.

text: Glen Shires: “Voice Driven Web Apps: Introduction to the Web Speech API”
Brandon Satrom: “Using voice to drive the web: Introduction to the Web Speech API”

specs.title: MediaStream processing API
description: this proposal makes HTML Streams the foundation for integrated Web media processing by creating a mixing and effects processing API for HTML Streams

specs.title: Audio processing API
description: introduces and compares two client-side APIs for processing and synthesizing real-time audio streams in the browser

specs.title: API for media resources
description: defines an API to access metadata information related to media resources on the Web
specifies the *MediaResource* interface

specs.title: Media source extensions
description: extends *HTMLMediaElement* to allow JavaScript to generate media streams for playback; this facilitates a variety of use cases like adaptive streaming and time shifting live streams
notes: This is the first working draft -- *January 2013*.

specs.title: Encrypted media extensions
description: extends *HTMLMediaElement* providing APIs to control playback of protected content
notes: W3C CEO Jeff Jaffe posted his perspectives on the first public working draft of this document <kbd>4</kbd>.
WebM Encryption, and ISO BMFF Common Encryption (CENC) is available in **Chrome** <kbd>3</kbd>.

text: Perspectives on Encrypted Media Extension Reaching First Public Working Draft

specs.title: Clipboard API
description: defines APIs for clipboard operations such as copy, cut and paste in web applications
specifies the `cut`, `copy`, and `paste` event types, and the `.clipboardData` event property

notes: The `.clipboardData` event property is implemented in **Chrome**, **Safari**, and **Opera**. A non-standard `clipboardData` global object is provided in **IE** (with different API; see demo linked below) -- *February 2013*.

text: Retrieving clipboard data from the `paste` event

specs.title: Fullscreen API
description: defines APIs for displaying document elements in full-screen mode
specifies the `.requestFullscreen()` Element method, and the document-properties `.fullscreenEnabled`, `.fullscreenElement`, and `.exitFullscreen()`

specs.title: Gamepad
description: defines a low-level API that represents gamepad devices
specifies the `navigator.gamepads` object, and the `gamepadconnected`, and `gamepaddisconnected` event types
**APIs defined here don't appear to be stable (Chrome currently implements navigator.webkitGetGamepads which is not defined here)**

specs.title: Pointer lock
description: defines an API that provides scripted access to raw mouse movement data while locking the target of mouse events to a single element and removing the cursor from view
specifies the `.requestPointerLock()` Element method, the document-properties `.pointerLockElement`, and `.exitPointerLock()`, and the `pointerlockchange`, and `pointerlockerror` event types`
**experimental implementations exist in Firefox, and WebKit**

specs.title: Screen orientation API
description: provides an API for web applications to be able to read the screen orientation state, to be informed when this state changes and to be able to lock the screen orientation to a specific state
extends the `screen` global object with the properties `.orientation`, `.lockOrientation()`, and `.unlockOrientation()`, and the `orientationchange` event type
**experimental implementation exists in Firefox**

specs.title: WebDriver
description: allows programs or scripts to introspect into, and control the behaviour of, a web browser

primarily intended to allow developers to write tests that automate a browser from a separate controlling process, but may also be implemented in such a way as to allow in-browser scripts to control a — possibly separate — browser

text: “WebDriver API Draft Published, Enables Remote Browser Control For Automated Tests”

specs.title: Geolocation API
description: defines an API that provides scripted access to geographical location information associated with the hosting device
specifies the `navigator.geolocation` object

specs.title: Notifications API
description: defines an API for displaying simple notifications to the user
notes: The W3C version of this standard is available under the name “Web notifications”.

specs.title: Battery status API
description: defines an API that provides information about the battery status of the hosting device
specifies the `navigator.battery` object

specs.title: Network information API
description: provides an API for web applications to access the underlying network information (connection info) of the device
specifies the `navigator.connection` object

specs.title: System information API
description: defines an API to provide web applications with access to various properties of the system which they are running on, e.g. battery status, current network bandwidth,  ambient brightness, atmospheric pressure
specifies the `navigator.system` object

specs.title: Messaging API
description: defines an API that provides access to messaging functionality in the device, including SMS, MMS and e-mail
specifies the `navigator.device` object

specs.title: Vibration API
description: defines an API that provides access to the vibration mechanism of the hosting device
specifies the `navigator.vibrate()` function

specs.title: Web alarms API
description: defines an API to provide access to the device alarm settings, which can schedule a notification or for an application to be started at a specific time; for example, some applications like alarm-clock, calendar or auto-update might need to utilize this API to trigger particular device behaviors at specified time points
specifies the `navigator.alarms` object
notes: This is the initial working draft -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: Contacts manager API
description: defines an API which offers a simple interface to manage user's contacts stored in the system's address book
notes: This is the initial working draft -- *March 2013*.

specs.title: Ambient light events
description: defines a means to receive events that correspond to a light sensor detecting the presence of a light
specifies the `devicelight` event type

specs.title: Device orientation events
description: defines several new DOM events that provide information about the physical orientation and motion of a hosting device
specifies the `deviceorientation`, `compassneedscalibration`, and `devicemotion` event types

text: Shwetank Dixit: “The W3C device orientation API: detecting orientation and acceleration”

temp: Be warned that, at present, the available implementations of this spec are non-interoperable (Chris Mills, Jan 2013)

specs.title: Proximity events
description: defines a means to receive events that correspond to a proximity sensor detecting the presence of a physical object
specifies the `deviceproximity`, and `userproximity` event types

specs.title: Touch events
description: defines a set of low-level events that represent one or more points of contact with a touch-sensitive surface, and changes of those points with respect to the surface and any DOM elements displayed upon it (e.g. for touch screens) or associated with it (e.g. for drawing tablets without displays)
specifies the `touchstart`, `touchend`, `touchmove`, and `touchcancel` event types

text: Chris Wilson & Paul Kinlan: “Touch And Mouse - Together Again For The First Time”

temp: Firefox 18 implemented this in favor of MozTouch events

specs.title: Pointer events
description: defines events and related interfaces for handling hardware agnostic pointer input from devices like a mouse, pen, or touchscreen
specifies the pointer event types, e.g. `pointerdown`, `pointerup`, `pointercancel`, `pointermove`
notes: This standard has been submitted by Microsoft in September 2012.

*“Pointer events give us a single unified event model to connect multiple pointers, regardless of their type, and have them interact with each other. This is not simple using the current model, and many things are not even possible. […] Pointer events are not breaking the web in any way, as they are an addition to mouse and touch events, not a replacement.”* - Paul Bakaus. See <kbd>4</kbd>.
Available in **IE10** (and a **Chromium** prototype; see <kbd>6</kbd>). Read the articles below for more information.

text: Adalberto Foresti: “Pointer Events Standardization Reaches Key Maturity Milestone at W3C, MS Open Tech Releases Second Drop of Pointer Events Prototype for WebKit”
“Prototype Chromium build with support for MS Pointer Events”
Jacob Rossi: “Learning more about Pointer Events as the W3C publishes Last Call Working Draft”

specs.title: UI events
description: extends the events and features defined in DOM Events Level 3

specs.title: IndieUI Events
description: provides an abstraction between physical, device-specific user interaction events and inferred user intent such as scrolling or changing values
focuses on granular user interface interactions such as scrolling the view, canceling an action, changing the value of a user input widget, selecting a range, placing focus on an object, etc.
notes: This is the first draft of this specification -- *January 2013*.

text: W3C Blog: “IndieUI: Events expands user interface interactions for mobile and more”

specs.title: IndieUI User context
description: provides a set of properties and methods related to the environmental context of a specific user, and a vehicle to access them to facilitate a Web application's ability to adapt to the user's needs; this is meant to provide information about whether a user is using a screen reader, screen magnifier, or other Assistive Technology, and to expose relevant user settings, allowing optimal adaptation of the Web application's user interface

specs.title: Web intents
description: defines a service discovery and light-weight RPC mechanism for web applications
notes: This is (was?) being proposed by Google. Mozilla has made a counter-proposal called “Web Activities” (which is in Firefox OS); see <kbd>4</kbd> -- *January 2013*.
See message <kbd>5</kbd>.

specs.title: Web intents: Local services
description: defines how Web Intents enabled User Agents can discover and communicate with local Web Intents Services

specs.title: Pick contacts intent
description: enables access to a user's address book service from inside a web application

specs.title: Pick media intent
description: enables access to a user's media gallery from inside a web application

specs.title: Web cryptography API
description: describes an API for performing basic cryptographic operations in web applications, such as hashing, signature generation and verification, and encryption and decryption
notes: This draft is **not stable**.
**Chrome**, **Safari**, and **non-stable Firefox** (version 21) implement the `crypto.getRandomValues()` function -- *updated February 2013*.

text: “PolyCrypt: A WebCrypto API Polyfill In JavaScript Funded by the US Department of Homeland Security”

specs.title: WebCrypto Key Discovery
description: describes a JavaScript API for discovering named, origin-specific pre-provisioned cryptographic keys for use with the Web Cryptography AP

specs.title: Programmable HTTP Caching and Serving
description: defines APIs for off-line serving of requests to HTTP resources using static and dynamic responses

specs.title: Web SQL database
description: defines an API for storing data in databases that can be queried using a variant of SQL

specs.title: Cross-origin resource sharing
description: defines a mechanism to enable client-side cross-origin requests
e.g. the server response contains a `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header which specifies if the web application is permitted to access the response data
notes: This standard is now a CR (candidate recommendation) -- *January 2013*.
There also exists a “Living standard” version of this standard (see <kbd>3</kbd>). According to the editor, it outh to be merged with the “HTML Living standard”.

specs.title: Content security policy
description: defines a policy language used to declare a set of content restrictions for a web resource, and a mechanism for transmitting the policy from a server to a client where the policy is enforced

for example, to mitigate XSS, a web application can declare from where it expects to load scripts, allowing the client to detect and block malicious scripts injected into the application by an attacker
specifies the `Content-Security-Policy` HTTP header
notes: This technology was invented by Mozilla.
Implemented in **Chrome**. For details, see Can-I-use <kbd>3</kbd>.

specs.title: Strict transport security
description: defines a mechanism enabling web sites to declare themselves accessible only via secure connections and/or for users to be able to direct their user agent(s) to interact with given sites only over secure connections

text: Mike West: “Confound Malicious Middlemen with HTTPS and HTTP Strict Transport Security”

specs.title: Uniform messaging policy
description: enables cross-site messaging that avoids Cross-Site-Request-Forgery and similar attacks that abuse HTTP cookies and other credentials
notes: In hiatus since April 2012.

specs.title: Permissions for device API access
description: identifies the permissions that are needed to use specific client-side APIs which grant access to sensitive data and operations

specs.title: Accessible Rich Internet Applications (ARIA)
description: provides an ontology of roles, states, and properties that define accessible user interface elements and can be used to improve the accessibility and interoperability of web content and applications
notes: A “practical guide for developers on how to add accessibility information to HTML elements” is available as a separate document; see <kbd>3</kbd> -- *February 2013*.
Shawn Henry provides useful information in his message <kdb>5</kdb> -- *March 2013*.

text: Shawn Henry: “WAI-ARIA Authoring Practices: Updated Guidance”

specs.title: Authoring accessible CSS
description: describes techniques for authoring accessible CSS

specs.title: Web application privacy best practices
description: describes privacy best practices for web applications, including those that might use device APIs

specs.title: Device API privacy requirements
description: provides definitions, use cases, and requirements for making device APIs more privacy-friendly

specs.title: Tracking preference expression (DNT)
description: defines the technical mechanisms for expressing a tracking preference via the DNT (Do Not Track) request header field in HTTP, via an HTML DOM property readable by embedded scripts, and via properties accessible to various user agent plug-in or extension APIs
specifically, the browser includes a `DNT: 1` header in HTTP requests
notes: W3C issued a call for prior art on Patent 8,156,206 <kbd>4</kbd> *(Feb 2013)*.
**Firefox**, **Chrome** and **Opera** support the `DNT` request header. The DNT functionallity has to be manually activated by the user, i.e. it’s disabled by default.

text: W3C Workshop: Do Not Track and Beyond
W3C: “Call for prior art on Patent 8,156,206”
Somini Sengupta: “Web Privacy Becomes a Business Imperative”

specs.title: Tracking selection lists
description: defines a format for interchangeable lists for blocking or allowing Web tracking elements and expected user-agent interpretation of this format
notes: This preliminary draft is currently labeled “not WG-consensus” -- *February 2013*.

specs.title: URL
description: this standard sets out to make URLs fully predictable and interoperable

specs.title: The “data” URI scheme
description: the “data” URI scheme allows inclusion of small data items as “immediate” data, as if it had been included externally
e.g. ``

text: Jose Jesus Perez Aguinaga: “One line browser notepad”

specs.title: Media fragments URI
description: specifies the syntax for constructing media fragment URIs and explains how to handle them when used over the HTTP protocol
e.g. `http://www.example.com/example.ogv#track=audio&t=10,20`

notes: Quote from article (linked below): “*The temporal dimension portion was implemented last year in **Chrome** and **Firefox** but the spatial dimension isn't supported in any current browser as of the time of writing.*” -- *January 2013*.

text: Use cases and requirements for media fragments
Fabrice Weinberg: “Media Fragments URI – Spatial Dimension”

specs.title: Encoding
description: while encodings have been defined to some extent, implementations have not always implemented them in the same way, have not always used the same labels, and often differ in dealing with undefined and former proprietary areas of encodings; this specification attempts to fill those gaps so that new implementations do not have to reverse engineer encoding implementations of the market leaders and existing implementations can converge

specs.title: MIME sniffing
description: describes an algorithm for determining the effective media type of HTTP responses that balances security and compatibility considerations
